hedline.hl1: Of S.U.V. Redesigns and Attitude Adjustments

abstract.p: Karleen Erhardt letter oints out threat to drivers of standard cars from huge SUVs, as well as their other drawbacks

block.p: Re ''S.U.V.'s to Be Redesigned to Reduce Risk to Cars'' (front page, Dec. 4): Direct collisions are not the only threat S.U.V.'s pose to drivers of standard cars. It is impossible to see around them when pulling out of a parking space, thus increasing the risk of accidents with other vehicles or pedestrians. At night the elevated headlights of S.U.V.'s blind car drivers in both the rear and side-view mirrors, distracting their attention from the road ahead.

Re ''S.U.V.'s to Be Redesigned to Reduce Risk to Cars'' (front page, Dec. 4): Direct collisions are not the only threat S.U.V.'s pose to drivers of standard cars. It is impossible to see around them when pulling out of a parking space, thus increasing the risk of accidents with other vehicles or pedestrians. At night the elevated headlights of S.U.V.'s blind car drivers in both the rear and side-view mirrors, distracting their attention from the road ahead.
This is not to mention the increased toxic emissions from S.U.V.'s we all must breathe or the way these behemoths fuel global warming.

When automakers put profit before public safety (as in ''Don't touch my cash cow''), I wonder if they ever think about the afterlife. Do they envision themselves endlessly rolling an S.U.V. up a steep slope, only to have it roll back down on them?
KARLEEN ERHARDT Port Jefferson Station, N.Y. Dec. 4, 2003
